author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Some Sri Lankans are questioning why their government wasn't better prepared for the country’s worst climate disaster in two decades. Cyclone Ditwah caused floods and landslides last week that killed more than 480 people. Nearly 200 thousand Sri Lankans have been displaced. And rescue and recovery efforts are still underway. 

Al Jazeera’s Minelle Fernandez reports from Kaduwela, a suburb of Colombo.

description:
Israel’s military has launched air strikes on at least three towns in southern Lebanon, Mahrouna, Jbaa, and al-Majadel, despite the ceasefire in place since last November.

According to Lebanon’s National News Agency, the attack on Jbaa on Thursday destroyed a building in a densely populated residential area and caused extensive damage to nearby structures.

Al Jazeera’s Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Libya has remained divided between two rival governments for over a decade.
The political split is deeply entrenched, blocking progress towards stability.
The UN has proposed a new roadmap to break the deadlock.
It calls for forming a unified government to lead the country forward.
This body would be responsible for organising national elections.
The plan faces significant political and security challenges.

Al Jazeera’s Malik Traina reports from Tripoli on the obstacles ahead.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
For decades, Africa was defined by aid, debt and development debates.

Today, the continent's critical minerals, rising consumer markets and young workforce are turning it into one of the world’s most strategic economic battlegrounds.

China, the United States and Europe are all vying for influence there - from infrastructure to clean energy and digital networks.

But across the continent, the focus has shifted - leaders want partnerships that deliver real industry, real jobs and real value for African people.

So as global rivals step up their game, can Africa finally choose partners on its own terms?
 
#aljazeera #africa #business #economy #minerals #criticalminerals #politics #aljazeeraenglish
title: Can Africa choose economic partners on its own terms? | Counting the Cost

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Pakistan’s Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province is facing a surge in violence as attacks by the Pakistani Taliban, also known as Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), intensify along the Afghan border.
More than 150 fighters have been killed in recent security raids, yet fear persists among residents.
In Swat district, a survivor described losing seventeen family members over two decades of militant persecution.
He narrowly escaped an IED blast near his home in November.
Despite repeated military operations, he says the threat has never fully disappeared.
Daily life is defined by warnings, restrictions, and fear, with even work, school, and hospital visits feeling unsafe.
Residents say only a genuine peace deal or decisive action can end the cycle of violence.

title: ‘Every day could be my last’: Pakistani man recounts decades of TTP persecution

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
France’s President Macron told China’s leader Xi that France and China must overcome their “differences” during a state visit to Beijing.
He urged China to use its influence on Russia to push for a ceasefire in Ukraine.
Macron called for a fairer, more balanced trade relationship between France and China and reforms to global economic governance.
China signalled its willingness to strengthen its strategic partnership with France, highlighting stability and multilateral cooperation.
During the visit, both nations signed 12 cooperation agreements covering investment, nuclear energy, and population-ageing initiatives.
Despite warm rhetoric and new deals, key tensions remain — especially over Russia, Ukraine, and global trade imbalances.

Al Jazeera’s Katrina Yu Reports from Beijing.

title: Macron tells Xi that China, France must overcome ‘differences’

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The US is ramping up military threats and rhetoric against Venezuela. With 15,000 US troops deployed in the Caribbean Sea, strikes on alleged drug boats, and more than 80 alleged traffickers killed, the escalating military presence in the region has Venezuelans on edge. What's really driving these two countries closer to war?

In this episode:

- Alejandro Velasco, Associate Professor of Latin Studies, New York University

Episode credits:

This episode was produced by Melanie Marich, Haleema Shah, Tracie Hunte, and Diana Ferrero with Phillip Lanos, Spencer Cline, Chloe K. Li, Fatima Shafiq, Farhan Rafid, Tamara Khandaker, and our guest host, Manuel Rapalo. It was edited by Kylene Kiang. 

Our sound designer is Alex Roldan. This episode was mixed by Rick Rush. Our video editors are Hisham Abu Salah and Mohannad al-Melhem. Alexandra Locke is The Take’s executive producer. Ney Alvarez is Al Jazeera’s head of audio.
title: How close is the US to war with Venezuela? | The Take

description:
US President Donald Trump has intensified attacks on Somali Americans and immigrants.
He claims they are 'destroying' the country amid rising anti-immigrant rhetoric.
Federal authorities are preparing an immigration crackdown in Minnesota.
Hundreds of undocumented Somalis could be targeted in the operation.
Minnesota hosts one of the largest Somali communities in the United States.
The move has heightened tensions within local Somali communities.

Al Jazeera’s Charles Stratford reports.

description:
Israeli warplanes have carried out air strikes on the towns of Mahrouna and Jbaa in southern Lebanon, according to Lebanon’s National News Agency, and the Israeli army threatened the residents of two other Lebanese towns of al-Majadel and Braashit with imminent attacks.
It is seen as a deliberate message that military strikes will continue alongside diplomacy.
Israel's stated aim is to pressure Hezbollah into full disarmament, ensuring negotiations proceed "under fire."
This persists despite a frequently violated ceasefire.

Al Jazeera’s Zeina Khodr reports reports from Beirut.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Israeli media report that Yasser Abu Shabab, an Israeli-backed Palestinian militia leader and a key Hamas target, has been killed in Rafah.
There is still no confirmation from his group, family, or official channels.
Details surrounding his death and who was behind it remain unclear.
Abu Shabab had been accused of looting humanitarian aid trucks, which his group claimed to be protecting.
His reported killing raises questions over the delivery of 80 aid trucks and Israel’s use of proxy groups in Gaza.
He operated mainly near the Kerem Abu Salem crossing and led a militia active in southern Gaza.
Uncertainty persists over the impact on local dynamics as Gaza enters the next phase of the ceasefire.

author: Al Jazeera English
description: As part of the October 10 ceasefire, Israeli troops pulled back to the so-called yellow line in Gaza. But Palestinians were left with mostly non-arable land, while fertile farmland behind the line remains under Israeli control. So what does a ceasefire mean if Palestinians are denied the land they need to grow their food?
title: Israel’s Evolving Starvation of Gaza

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The war in Sudan has created the worst humanitarian crisis in the world. How did the fighting begin? Who are the two main sides – the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF)? And what are the main factors driving the war now? 

Watch this #AJStartHere Sudan explainer with Sandra Gathmann to understand what’s happening. 

Chapters:
00:14 - The two main sides and areas of control
00:54 - Sudan’s diversity and ethnic divisions
01:18 - Omar al-Bashir and the Janjaweed
01:32 - The Darfur genocide in the early 2000s
02:06 - How the RSF emerged from the Janjaweed
03:34 - The 2019 protests and the fall of Omar al-Bashir
04:11 - The 2021 military coup and outbreak of war
05:53 - RSF violence in Darfur
08:07 - How both sides are getting support from outside Sudan
09:40 - How gold is fuelling the war
11:18 - How diplomacy to end the war has failed so far

This episode features:

Mahitab Mahgoub | Non-resident Fellow, Tahrir Institute For Middle East Policy

Yassmin Abdel-M
title: Watch this to understand the war in Sudan | Start Here

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Mohammed and his daughter face the emotional fallout of his political activism in Gaza and imprisonment in Israel, that left her to grow up without him.

A fractured family tries to heal itself across borders and generations. Palestinian Mohammed Dahman, from Gaza, served nearly 20 years in Israeli jails when he was younger. This powerful observational film follows Mohammed and his daughter, Mai, as they confront the emotional scars left by his years of absence, both in jail and as a political activist. Now living in Norway, Mohammed fears growing old far from Gaza and sets out to retrieve the prison letters he once sent home, hoping they might help repair his strained relationship with Mai. His visit back to Gaza stirs memories of political struggle, friendship and sacrifice, while Mai in Norway grapples with the resentment of a childhood without him. When he finally returns, father and daughter face the painful truths of the past as they read the letters together - moments of love,
title: Letters From A Palestinian Prisoner | Al Jazeera World Documentary

description:

Heatwaves are already occurring far more often, and experts warn the worst may still be ahead. 
The surge is being driven by the double impact of long-term global warming and shifting climate patterns.

Al Jazeera’s Cara Legg reports.

The military carried out drone strikes on tents housing displaced families in al-Mawasi.

Israeli forces have violated the ceasefire agreement nearly 600 times, since it took effect nearly eight weeks ago. 

Al Jazeera’s Hani Mahmoud is in Gaza City and has more details on the latest ceasefire breaches

description: Minnesota state senator Omar Fateh says President Trump’s hostile rhetoric towards Somali Americans is a strategy to win support ahead of the midterm elections.
title: Trump’s criticism of Somalis in US just “political theatre”

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin says southern Ukraine and the eastern Donbas region will be taken “by military means or otherwise”.
He made the comments in an interview with Indian media.
They come after talks between US special envoy Steve Witkoff and Putin in Moscow on Tuesday.
The Kremlin says no compromise was found on the issue of territory.
Ukraine says it will not accept recognition of Russian sovereignty over land it's occupied.

Al Jazeera’s Yulia Shapovalova has more from Moscow, Russia.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
The US insists it's bombing boats to stop Venezuelan drug smugglers from flooding America with narcotics.
But Venezuela contends that Washington wants regime change and to get its hands on huge reserves of oil. 

Al Jazeera’s Phil Lavelle is in Ceiba in Puerto Rico where a big US military presence is on standby for a possible attack. 

A reminder: Al Jazeera has been trying to report from inside Venezuela but like most foreign media, we have not been allowed to enter the country at this time.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo are due to sign a US-mediated peace agreement — a deal Washington hopes will reset one of Africa’s most volatile conflicts. 
But with rebel forces still entrenched, accusations of foreign backing unresolved, and global powers competing for DRC’s vast mineral wealth, the path to peace is far from straightforward.

Al Jazeera’s Catherine Soi reports.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Nigeria’s president has appointed a new defence minister a week after declaring a security state of emergency, partly triggered by school kidnappings.
Two weeks ago, 300 students were abducted from a school in central Nigeria. 

Al Jazeera’s Ahmed Idris reports from Papiri in central Nigeria where parents are waiting for news of their children's whereabouts.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
President Donald Trump has stepped up rhetoric against Somali immigrants, accusing them of "destroying" the US. It's the second day Trump's attacked the community.
It comes as federal authorities prepare to launch an immigration crackdown, targeting hundreds of undocumented Somalis in the state of Minnesota.

Al Jazeera’s Patty Culhane has more from Washington, DC.

Trump took particular aim at Democrat congresswoman Ilhan Omar, who was born in Somalia.
He says she should "be thrown out of the country." Omar responded to the president's threats. 

Omar Fateh is a Minnesota State Senator. He says language matters and hateful rhetoric has consequences.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Social media accounts have begun going offline for thousands of young Australians as the country begins rolling out a landmark ban. The law requires platforms to block under-16s from having accounts on apps like TikTok and Instagram. The ban is being challenged in the High Court, but accounts are already disappearing ahead of a December 10th deadline.

Al Jazeera’s Danielle Robertson reports from Sydney.

author: Al Jazeera English
description:
Thousands of people have fled the Sudanese city of el-Fasher since the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of it in late October. But the fate of even more people who’ve been left behind remains unknown since (as) satellite imagery shows no signs of civilian life in the city. Those who’ve fled el-Fasher say they’re afraid their loved ones may have been killed, with reports of mass graves and burning of bodies around the city. 

A warning: Some viewers may find the details in this report disturbing. Al Jazeera’s Hiba Morgan reports.
